I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Independent  State  of  Samoa  for  subprogram 2  of  the  Economic  Recovery  Support 
Program (ERSP). 1 
 
The Samoa ERSP is a program cluster of two subprogram loans totaling $26.82 million. 2 
2. 
The  ERSP  cluster  aims  to  assist  Samoa’s  economic  recovery  and  movement  to  a  higher 
medium-term  growth  rate,  following  the  double  impact  of  the  global  economic  crisis  and  the 
September  2009  tsunami.  Subprogram 2  of  the  program  cluster  will  support  improved  fiscal 
management  and  structural  measures  that  will  help  place  the  economy  on  a  sustainable 
medium-term growth path. Budget support will finance the fiscal deficit to enable raised levels of 
capital  spending  over  the  medium  term.  This  will  be  complemented  by  measures  that  enable 
targeting of services to protect the vulnerable and by engagement with key stakeholders. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Samoa’s  real  per  capita  income  growth  since  the  mid-1990s  has  been  significantly 
higher than for most other Pacific island countries underpinned by prudent fiscal and monetary 
policies and structural reforms. Its reforms have steadily strengthened the economy’s resilience 
to  external  shocks.  The  economy  is  led  by  the  tourism,  agriculture,  and  fishing  industries 
enabled  by  Samoa’s  natural  beauty,  well-educated  labor  force,  and  ample  land  and  marine 
resources.  Remittances,  typically  equivalent  to  around  25%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP), 
play  an  important  role  in  the  economy.  Despite  this  sound  base,  the  Samoan  economy  was 
severely affected by the global recession commencing in 2008. Local manufacturing jobs were 
lost, while offshore jobs were lost in the tuna processing industry. Remittances were down 18% 
year-on-year at the weakest point. In addition, construction recorded a significant decline, while 
agriculture and fishing suffered from poor harvests. As a result, real GDP fell by 5.1% in FY2009, 
the worst slump in 2 decades. Government revenue was 4.7% below budget estimates, and a 
deficit  of  4.3%  of  GDP  was  sustained.  Adding  to  this,  the  physical  cost  of  the  2009  tsunami, 
which was estimated at $60 million (over 10% of GDP), weakened the economic outlook. 3 
 
4. 
The program cluster was designed to support the government’s response to the external 
shocks through short-term fiscal adjustments, as well as to maintain the reform agenda as the 
foundation  for  continuing  growth.  The  ERSP  policy  matrix  was  developed  from  a  country-
developed matrix, which sets out the government’s priority policy actions from the Strategy for 
the  Development  of  Samoa  (SDS),  2008–2012  and  supporting  sector  plans.  This  matrix  was 
used by the World Bank to release funds in parallel with subprogram 1 and subsequently by the 
Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID),  in  collaboration  with  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB),  to  release  performance-linked  budget  support  in  June  2011. 4 Due 
attention  has  been  given  to  ensuring  country  ownership,  understanding  government  capacity,

 building  on  consultation  processes,  and  embedding  the  program  within  ADB’s  long-term 
commitment to assistance. 5  
 
5. 
Subprogram 1,  which  was  completed  in  2010,  achieved  improved  fiscal  management 
and  implementation  of  structural  measures  to  aid  economic  recovery  and  help  protect  the 
delivery of basic services to the vulnerable. Through the program, and among other reforms, the 
public  finance  management  (PFM)  reform  plan  was  pushed  ahead,  the  pace  of  state-owned 
enterprise  (SOE)  reform  was  raised, the telecommunications  sector  was  liberalized,  actions  to 
meet  the  needs  of  those  affected  by  the  tsunami  were  taken,  and  the  primary  school  fee-free 
scheme was introduced.  
 
6. 
The  ERSP  loan  and  financing  from  other  development  partners  supported  the 
government’s  efforts  to  fund  fiscal  deficits  and  raise  development  (capital)  expenditure  in 
FY2010  and  FY2011.  This  stimulated  economic  activity  and  supported  the  private  sector. 
Activity  generated  by  post-tsunami reconstruction  work  was  largely  responsible for  holding  the 
contraction to 0.2% in FY2010. Growth is estimated to have been 2.1% of GDP in FY2011, as a 
result  of  reconstruction  work  and  the  rebound  in  transport,  communications,  tourism, 
remittances, and manufacturing activities. 6  
 
7. 
Subprogram 2  completes  the  program  reform  agenda  under  the  ERSP  cluster. 
Subprogram 2  is  consistent  with  the  strategic  focus  of  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  for 
2008–2012 7 to address binding constraints to growth, including deficiencies in access to public 
services  and  in  the  quality  of  public  service  delivery,  and  weaknesses  in  the  private  sector-
enabling environment. Subprogram 2 of the ERSP cluster supports the government’s economic 
and financial reform program in coordination with key development partners including Australia, 
the European Union, and the World Bank.  
 
8. 
During  preparation  of  subprogram 1,  13  triggers  were  identified  for  subprogram 2. 
Consultation  with  the  government  on  the  evolution  of  priorities  and  the  context  of  reform  has 
allowed 19 prior policy actions to be finalized for subprogram 2. The instances in which triggers 
did not directly translate into a single policy action comprised the following:

9. 
Of the 19 policy actions, 17 have been fully accomplished and gazettal of the Electricity 
Act  2010  and  cabinet  consideration  of  the  personal  property  securities  bill  are  at  advanced 
stages. Completion of these two actions are conditions to the effectivity of the loan agreement. 
The policy matrix provides details on the status of subprogram 2 policy actions. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

10. 
The  impact  will  be  the  achievement  of  a  higher  and  more  inclusive  economic  growth 
path.  The  outcome  will  be  economic  recovery  combined  with  protection  of  the  vulnerable  and 
the country’s fiscal position. ADB financing will be used to help meet the government’s overall 
budget  financing  needs,  which  have  increased  as  a  result  of  post-tsunami  investment  in 
infrastructure and buildings.  
 
C. 

Outputs 

11. 
The policy actions of subprogram 2 are grouped within five output areas: (i) addressing 
post-tsunami  reconstruction  needs,  (ii)  maintenance  of  fiscal  responsibility,  (iii)  productivity-
enhancing  structural  and  governance  improvements,  (iv)  targeted  support  to  the  most 
vulnerable  members  of  the  community,  and  (v)  improved  consultation  and  engagement  with 
stakeholders. Policy actions in support of these output areas are discussed below.  
 
12. 
Output  1:  Post-tsunami  reconstruction  needs  addressed.  In  response  to  the 
reconstruction  requirements  following  the  2009  tsunami,  and  in  an  effort  to  stimulate  the 
sluggish  economy  and  create  local  jobs,  Samoa’s  capital  expenditure  was  raised  50%  above 
FY2009  levels  in  FY2010  and  was  26%  above  FY2009  levels  in  FY2011,  utilizing  the  fiscal 
space  generated  by  the  subprogram 1  loan.  In  compliance  with  the  program,  the  FY2010  and 
FY2011  capital  expenditure  were  guided  by  an  interim  update  of  the  public  sector  investment 
plan, which included a post-tsunami reconstruction plan to be implemented over a 4-year period. 
Reconstruction, including construction of new infrastructure, facilities, and housing in relocation 
areas, was largely completed by the end of FY2011. 
 
The need for increased capital expenditure remains. As well as the completion of post-
13. 
tsunami  reconstruction  work  (a  new  cross-island  road,  further  seawalls,  completion  of 
permanent water supplies, and four schools), the national infrastructure strategic plan endorsed 
by the cabinet development committee sets out government investment plans across a number

14. 
Output  2:  Fiscal  responsibility  maintained.  Output  2  will  support  the  medium-term 
goals of fiscal discipline and improving transparency, accountability, efficiency, and equity in the 
use of public funds. A sound fiscal framework promotes the operational and fiscal sustainability 
of capital projects. To promote fiscal sustainability, the FY2012 budget was prepared against a 
medium-term  expenditure  framework  (MTEF)  that  included  a  fiscal  strategy  statement,  the 
preparation  of  forward  estimates,  and  a  statement  of  government  operations  prepared  in 
accordance with International Monetary Fund (IMF) Government Finance Statistics standards.

15. 
The macroeconomic and budget aggregates of the FY2012 budget show an expectation 
of  a  return  to  sound  economic  growth  levels  (Table  1).  Heightened  growth,  and  with  it  higher 
revenue  receipts,  will  support  efforts to  reduce  the  budget  deficit,  which  is  expected  to remain 
outside  target  levels  through  FY2014.  Nonetheless,  the  FY2012  budget  has  brought  forward 
fiscal consolidation in comparison to the MTEF underlying the FY2011 budget, which projected 
a  deficit  of  8.6%  in  FY2012  and  a  similar  level  in  out-years.  The  fiscal  consolidation  has  both 
squeezed current expenditure and included efforts to raise revenue. Revenue measures focus 
on improved compliance and some raising of taxes, fees, and charges without undermining the 
impetus for private sector-led growth. The government is aware that the intended annual fiscal 
deficits of over 6% over this period hold risks—for example, the government would find it hard to 
adjust to any external shocks—and macroeconomic management and fiscal sustainability have 
therefore been prioritized. 
 
Subprogram 2  provides  for  maintaining  an  MTEF  that  is  consistent  with  fiscal 
16. 
sustainability,  preserving  a  low  risk  of  debt  distress  as  assessed  by  the IMF.  The government 
has acted to reduce the level of fiscal stimulus that proved so successful in returning Samoa to 
a  steady  growth  path.  Elements  framing  the  budget  include  the  following:  (i)  priority  has  been 
given to implementation of the tsunami recovery plan and spending on focal areas highlighted in 

                                                
8   The  cabinet development  committee comprises  the  cabinet,  chief  executive  officers  of ministries and  SOEs,  and 

senior officials.  

 

 the SDS; (ii) current expenditure as a percentage of GDP is forecast to be below the target rate 
as a result of reduced expenditure programs of ministries and corporations through FY2014, in 
line  with  the  aim  to  reduce  the  budget  deficit; 9 (iii)  personnel  costs  as  a  percentage  of  total 
current  expenditure  have  exceeded  the  target  range  because  of  the  inclusion  of  SOE  salary 
costs  for  the  first  time  in  FY2012  in  compliance  with  the  IMF  Government  Finance  Statistics 
format,  but  the  flat  out-year  trend  demonstrates  commitment  to  restraining  this  cost  element; 
and (iv) the government debt strategy aims to constrain new borrowing in the medium term to 
reduce  debt,  in  line  with  the  subprogram 2  commitment  to  maintaining  a  “low  level  of  debt 
distress” rating.   
 
17. 
Samoa has a good track record in prudently managing public debt, almost all of which is 
external. In 2010, the IMF advised the use of concessional financing to ensure the capacity to 
absorb  future  shocks  without  risking  an  unsustainable  debt  burden. 10  In  FY2011,  the 
government  entered  into  two  new  concessional  loans  from  the  People’s  Republic  of  China 
totaling ST52 million, but the IMF assesses that Samoa remains at low risk of debt distress. 11 
Implementation of the debt management strategy (approved by the cabinet in December 2010) 
will  aid  in  the  medium-term  stabilization  of  debt  below  the  target  ceiling  (initially  breached  in 
FY2010).  
 
18. 
Samoa’s  PFM  reform  plan  provides  the  foundation  for  sound  budget  formulation  and 
implementation,  and  has  been  guided  by  the  findings  of  the  2010  public  expenditure  and 
financial  accountability  (PEFA)  assessment.  Subprogram 2  supports  the  completion  of  key 
elements  of  phase 1  of  the  PFM  reform  plan:  (i)  bringing  the  public  accounts  up  to  date, 
completing the treasury instruction; (ii) use of the Samoa expenditure and revenue forecasting 
inform  the  MTEF;  (iii)  development  of  a  medium-term  debt  strategy;  and 
model 
(iv) completion of  a  development cooperation  policy.  In  December  2010, the  cabinet  endorsed 
implementation of phase 2 of the PFM reform plan, in line with subprogram 2, which will include 
(i)  integration  of  development  partner  funding  in  budget  estimates;  (ii)  improved  budget 
performance measures linked to the SDS and sector plans; (iii) establishment of a procurement 
unit  in  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF);  (iv)  development  of  an  internal  audit  framework; 
(v) implementation of the debt management strategy; and (vi) development of a communications 
strategy  to  strengthen  consultation  and  dialogue  on  policy  reform,  investment  planning,  and 
budget strategy. 
 
19. 
The  government  has  demonstrated  its  practical  intent  to  continued  transparency,  as 
promoted by subprogram 2, through the public release of the 2010 IMF Article IV Staff Report. 
Other  key  economic  and  fiscal  documents—PEFA,  budget  papers  and  statements,  quarterly 
economic updates—are also publicly available through government websites.  
 
20. 
Output  3:  Productivity  enhancing  structural  and  governance  improvements. 
Structural  and  governance  improvements  will  provide  the  productivity  gains  necessary  to 
support  medium-term  growth.  There  are  26  SOEs  in  Samoa;  under  subprogram 2,  the 
government  is  bringing  these  into  compliance  with  the  Public  Bodies  (Performance  and 
Accountability) Act, 2001 on the appointment of board members. The boards of 16 SOEs were 
dismissed  in  early  2011  and  a  rigorous  process  was  entered  into  to  identify  and  appoint  new 
directors. This was done through a three-person independent selection committee, making use 

to

 of  clear  and  transparent  selection  guidelines,  and  over  300  candidates  were  interviewed.  The 
Composition Act passed in the August parliamentary session amended all of the SOE-specific 
acts to align the selection and appointment process to that set out in the Public Bodies Act and 
regulations.  The  16  SOEs  had  new  boards  appointed  by  the  cabinet  in  late  August,  while  the 
board positions for the remaining 10 SOEs are to be advertised subsequently. 
 
21. 
In  addition  to  improving  the  oversight  of  SOEs  by  the  boards,  the  government  has 
sought  opportunities  to  divest  SOEs  as  part  of  subprogram 2.  SamoaTel  was  privatized  in 
March  2011  when  the  government  sold  75%  of  its  shareholding  to  Blue  Sky  SamoaTel 
Investment  and  placed  the  remaining  25%  in  the  Unit  Trust  of  Samoa,  which  will  pay  the 
government the agreed value of the shares within 5 years. The government intends to privatize 
the  Agriculture  Stores  Corporation  in  2012,  having  allocated  funds  for  undertaking  a  scoping 
study in the FY2012 budget, which will update and build on earlier  work undertaken with ADB 
support. 12 Legislation  has  been  passed  creating  the  Office  of  the  Power  Regulator,  which 
separates  governance  and  operational  responsibilities  in  the  electricity  sector.  Follow-through 
on implementation of the office is demonstrated by the government’s FY2012 budget allocation.  

 
22. 
The  legal  environment  for  business  is  also  being  improved  under  subprogram 2. 
Improvement in the climate for foreign investment is supported by amendments to the Foreign 
Investment  Act,  2000,  creating  greater  clarity  in  the  scope  of  both  reserved  and  restricted 
business areas, as well as putting in place clear criteria for adding to, or removing from, either of 
these  lists.  These  have  been  approved  by  the  cabinet  for  tabling  in  the  October  sitting  of 
Parliament.  The  intended  amendments  are  compliant  with  Samoa’s  accession  to  the  World 
Trade  Organization  and  were  subject  to  widespread  stakeholder  consultation.  Foreign 
investment regulations supporting the amended act have been approved for assent by the head 
of  state.  Prior  to  this,  there  were  no  regulations.  A  Personal  Property  Securities  Act  is  being 
prepared, which will allow moveable assets to be used as credit security, to be approved by the 
cabinet  ahead  of  the  December  2011  parliamentary  sitting.  With  limited  parliamentary  sitting 
(20–25  days  a  year),  a  clear  directive  from  the  cabinet  for  tabling  of  a  bill  in  Parliament  is 
demonstrative of government commitment to move forward.  
 
23. 
Output  4:  Targeted  support  for  the  most  vulnerable  members  of  the  community. 
The government  is mainstreaming  vulnerability  issues  into  its  policy  considerations,  supported 
by  subprogram 2.  The  findings  of  the  2008  household  income  and  expenditure  survey  have 
been  made  publicly  available  and  were  considered  by  the  cabinet.  Key  sector  plans  include 
specific  consideration  of  the  service  needs  of  the  vulnerable,  and  so  support  the  financing  of 
improved  services  to  the  most  vulnerable.  As  part  of  subprogram 2,  the  identification  of  the 
vulnerable  and  understanding  of  their  needs  in  a  policy  sense  has  been  improved  by  cabinet 
consideration  of  the  poverty  report  and  findings  of  the  household  income  and  expenditure 
survey.  During  preparation  of  the  FY2012  budget,  issues  highlighted  by  Samoa’s  second 
progress  report  on  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  and  specific  papers  on  vulnerability 
issues (remittances and minimum wage) were considered by the cabinet.  
 
24. 
Under  subprogram 2,  the  government  has  acted  on  its  subprogram 1  commitment, 
implementing the school free-fees scheme for the 2010 and 2011 school years with the support 
of  AusAID  and  the  New  Zealand  Aid  Programme  to  enable  more  children  to  enroll  in  primary 
school.  The  scheme  provides  a  payment  for  each  child  enrolled  (and  additional  amounts)  to 
government  and  mission  schools  at  the  primary  level  and  removes  the  requirement  for  these 
students  to  pay  school  fees.  Other  benefits  identified  as  arising  from  this  scheme  include  an

D. 
 
26. 
to 
SDR 6,863,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the program. The loan will 
have  a  24-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  an  interest  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum 
during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum  thereafter,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions 
set forth in the draft loan agreement. The loan size was determined after consideration of (i) the 
estimated impact of the global economic crisis and the projected deficit financing requirements 
for  the  FY2012  national  budget  estimated  at  $47.8  million;  (ii) the  availability  of  additional 
funding  from  other  development  partners  in  the  event  the  government  is  unable  to  meet  this 
financial requirement; (iii) the significance and complexity of the policy actions of the ERSP, and 
the  budgetary  resources  and  political  capital  required  to  implement  the  program  successfully; 
and  (iv)  the  conformity  of  the  ERSP  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  (footnote 7).  The 
determination  of  loan  size  took  into  account  the  government’s  demonstrated  commitment  to 
implement a policy agenda, as evidenced by the policy actions achieved from 2009 to date. 
 
27. 
Implementation of subprogram 1 has been a positive experience for Samoa (paras. 5–6). 
It has allowed Samoa to increase its capital expenditure as well as further strengthening public 
sector  management.  More  broadly,  ADB’s  portfolio  in  Samoa  is  performing  well  and  good 
progress  is  being made towards  targets  in  the  country  partnership strategy  results framework. 
The  proposed  loan  size  is  within  the  established  lending  allocation,  and  is  included  in  ADB’s 
country operations business plan. 13

E. 

 
Implementation Arrangements 

28. 
The program cluster period is from 1 March 2009 to 30 December 2011. Subprogram 2 
is being implemented from March 2010 to December 2011, with monitoring continuing through 
2012. Subprogram 2 will be provided as a single tranche loan of $10.82 million to be disbursed 
when the government has met the conditions for effectiveness, including completion of agreed 
prior policy actions as set forth in the policy matrix. 14 

 
The  loan  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  to  Samoa  according  to  ADB’s  simplified 
29. 
disbursement  procedures. 15 The  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign  exchange 
costs  (excluding  local  taxes  and  duties)  of  items  produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member

 countries;  items  in  the  list  of  ineligible  items 16 and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral  sources  are  excluded.  Loan  proceeds  disbursed  against  imports  will  require  a

development  assistance,  is  at  least  equal  to  or  greater  than  the  amount  of  the  loan  to  be

be used to support public expenditure objectives under the program. 

 
The  MOF  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  will  oversee  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory 
30. 
actions, ensuring that the reforms agreed to by the government and ADB are carried out on time. 
Resources from ongoing regional technical assistance will be provided to help the government 
meet the tranche conditions. 17 The MOF will also be responsible for the overall implementation 
of  subprogram 2,  including  all  policy  actions,  program  administration,  disbursements,  and 
maintenance of all program records. A program coordinating committee (including the MOF and 
the central bank) was established under subprogram 1 and will be responsible for coordinating 
this  subprogram,  as  well  as  any  similar  programs  prepared  with  development  partners. 18 The 
program  coordinating  committee  will  meet  at  least  quarterly  to  monitor  progress  and  oversee 
implementation of the program, inviting, as appropriate, line agencies of the borrower, ADB, and 
other development partners to participate in meetings.  

 
The coordinating committee responsible for monitoring and reporting on implementation 
31. 
of  subprogram 1  will  continue  this  role  through  subprogram 2.  The  committee  will  (i)  within 
3 months of loan effectiveness, establish and maintain a performance evaluation system for the 
program,  which  will  be  derived  from  the  design  and  monitoring  framework,  policy  letter,  and 
policy  matrix;  and  (ii)  monitor  and  report  to  ADB,  on  a  biannual  basis  over  the  term  of  the 
program, the implementation of policy actions and their impact on budget outcomes, in line with 
the  program  impact  and  outcome  indicators  agreed  with  the  government.  As  the  impact  and 
outcome  of  the  program  will  be  most  clearly  felt  beyond  the  period  of  its  implementation, 
monitoring  will  continue  to  be  undertaken  by  the  MOF  for  at  least  12  months.  Impact  and 
outcome monitoring will maximize use of the government’s own processes to ensure efficiency. 
A  completion  report  will  be  prepared  within  1  year  following  the  end  of  the  program  cluster  to 
evaluate  its  overall  performance.  ADB  will  also  conduct  a  post-program  review  to  assess 
progress  against  the  medium-term  indicators  of  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  and  the 
medium-term program direction of the policy matrix. 
 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Economic and Financial 

32. 
The Samoan economy was one of the more severely affected in the Pacific by the global 
economic  crisis (para.  3). The  economy  is  rebuilding  slowly,  with  a  contraction  of  just  0.2%  in 
FY2010. Medium-term growth prospects are sound, with the tourism industry being a key driver 
of  growth;  manufacturing  and  agriculture  also  hold  potential  for  greater  growth.  In  all  these 
sectors,  economic growth  prospects rest  on the private  sector  which,  although small,  is  active 
and  holds  potential  for  job  growth.  Reforms  have  improved  the  quality  of  PFM  since  2009, 
guided by PEFA assessments. 19 The MTEF provides a plan for economic recovery and growth.

 Through  the  increased  pace  of  fiscal  consolidation  set  out  in  the  FY2012  budget,  the 
government is prioritizing macroeconomic stability.  
 
B. 

Governance 

Samoa  is  considered  to  have  performed  well  above  the  Pacific  average  in  regard  to 
33. 
governance.  Samoa  has  made  incremental  improvements  to  governance  across  a  range  of 
areas, and has exemplified political stability and rule of law. Regulatory quality and government 
effectiveness  have  been  the  weaker  areas,  but  actions  to  revise  business  legislation,  improve 
regulation, and reform SOEs can be expected to show improvements.  
 
34. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOF.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  ADB  reserves  the  right  to  investigate,  directly  or  through  its 
agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the program. 
To support these efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the 
loan  agreement.  These  measures  will  complement  the  actions  under  way  to  improve  financial 
accountability  and  anticorruption  measures,  which  are  being  put  in  place  by  the  government 
with the support of its development partners.  
 
C. 

Poverty and Social 

35. 
The program will help the government reduce poverty incidence and improve long-term 
growth  prospects.  Policy  reforms  supported  by  the  program  are  expected  to  have  significant 
poverty  and  social  benefits,  including  indirect  impact  to  gender  equality  and  women’s 
empowerment.  The  continuation  of  efforts  to  rebuild  following  the  tsunami  will  be  supported 
under output 1, thus addressing the needs of the vulnerable group of tsunami victims. Improved 
PFM  will  allow  the  government  to  dedicate  more  resources  to  pro-poor  expenditures  and  to 
promote  more  efficient  service  delivery.  The  cabinet’s  consideration  of  the  findings  of  the 
household  income  and  expenditure  survey,  poverty  assessment,  and  progress  toward  the 
Millennium  Development Goals  demonstrates this  commitment.  Benefits will  be  accrued  in the 
short term  through  the  facilitation  of  the  government’s  planned  budgetary  expenditure,  in 
particular  on  social  services,  and  in  the  medium-to-long term  both  through  an  improved 
understanding within the government of poverty issues, and through implementation of reforms 
to  SOEs,  which  are  expected  to  improve  services  (output  3).  Given  existing  gender  gaps, 
improved social services are expected to particularly benefit women. 20 
 
D. 

Safeguards 

The program is classified category C, with no significant adverse environmental impacts 

36. 
identified. No involuntary resettlement or impact on indigenous people is expected.  
 
E. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

37.  Major risks and mitigating measures are outlined in Table 2 and described in detail in the 
risk assessment and risk management plan. 21 The potential benefits from reducing the impact of 
the  global  economic  crisis  and  providing  for  post-tsunami  reconstruction  with  supporting 
structural and governance initiatives are considered to outweigh the risks. Indeed, the costs of 
inaction could be substantial—a continued decline in the fiscal situation, with resultant damage 
to the operations of the private sector and implications for the government’s ability to fund basic 
social services and address environmental concerns.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

 
38. 
The  government  has  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  program  cluster  and 
subprogram 2  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement as described in detail in the loan documents. 
 
39. 
Specific  assurances. In addition to the standard assurances, the government and the 
MOF  have  given  the  following  assurances,  which  are  incorporated  in  the  legal  documents: 
(i) the government  will  (a)  maintain  the  policies adopted  and  actions  taken  prior to  the  date of 
the  loan  agreement  for  subprogram 2,  as  described  in  the  development  policy  letter  and  the 
policy  matrix,  for  the  duration  of  the  ERSP  and  subsequently,  (b)  promptly  adopt  the  other 
policies and the other actions as specified in the development policy letter and the policy matrix, 
and (c) ensure that such policies and actions continue in effect for the duration of the ERSP and 
subsequently; and (ii) the government and the program implementing agencies will ensure that 
throughout the implementation of subprogram 2, adequate budgetary allocations of the required 
counterpart  funds  are  made,  approved,  and  released  in  a  timely  manner  to  support  program 
implementation. 
 
40. 
Condition  for  loan  effectiveness.  The  loan  will  become  effective  only  after  the 
government  has  satisfactorily  fulfilled  all  conditions  for  the  release  of  the  single  tranche  of 
subprogram 2.  Gazettal  of  the  Electricity  Act  2010  and  cabinet  consideration  of  the  personal 
property securities bill are outstanding, but are expected to be completed by November 2011.  
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION   

 
41. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various 
currencies equivalent to SDR6,863,000 to the Independent State of Samoa for subprogram 2 of 
the  Economic  Recovery  Support  Program,  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources,  with  an 
interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum 
thereafter; for a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and 
conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  agreement 
presented to the Board.
